OK well this is what I needed to hear. Thanks Joel! I am using my own 
impl=
ementation of NEAT and I am going to add the real-time methods so 
I can tu=
rn it to steady-state evolution. I'll reuse most of the 
existing rtNEAT co=
de I used before, though. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <=
lehman.154@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Peter,
> 
> I would highly recommend using a =
steady-state GA with novelty 
search.
> I realize this poses a problem for =
many people who use NEAT because
> the only steady-state capable distributi=
on I am aware of is the C++
> rtNEAT package. Using novelty search with a g=
enerational GA may 
cause
> the dynamics of novelty search to be hurt. 
> 
=
> The reason a generational GA may not work as well is that novelty
> searc=
h uses an archive of past behaviors plus the behaviors of the
> current pop=
ulation to calculate the novelty scores. In a 
generational
> GA, this will=
 lead to large discrete changes in the novelty 
landscape
> (as the entire =
population changes at once), and will complicate the
> search process. The =
gradients of novelty may completely change with
> each passing generation, =
and lead to little global progress in the
> search for novelty. A possible =
solution would be simply *not* to
> include the current generation in the n=
ovelty scores with a
> generational GA.
> 
> However, this also has a downs=
ide: without the population being
> included in the novelty scores, there w=
ould then be no impetus for
> novelty search to maintain a behaviorally div=
erse population 
(although
> NEAT's speciation functions may cause this to =
not be disastrous).
> Without a behaviorally diverse population, there may =
be 
a "forgetting"
> problem where the novelty search population converges =
on a 
particular
> area of the behavioral space, and other previous areas o=
f novelty
> space no longer have representation in the population (potentia=
l
> stepping stones have been lost). To combat this problem, you could
> in=
troduce an operator that will clone individuals from the archive 
of
> past=
 behaviors, and place them back into the population.
> 
> It may be easier/=
more effective to extend whatever NEAT distribution
> you are using to be s=
teady state, or switch to the rtNEAT 
distribution.
> 
> Joel
>

eat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> wrote:

ountered a problem I need to ask you about. Is it really 
necessary

can

same dynamics would be applied with the generational-based 
NEAT?

you give me a suggestion? I appreciate any help.

> > Peter

> > answe=
rs
> > > to this kind of question, but here is my guess for the moment:  
>=

> > > novelty search may have a tendency to avoid stagnation alre=
ady 
> > because
> > > it includes the current population along with the ar=
chive when 
it

w 
> > historically,
> > > the population is still repelling itself away fr=
om where it is
> > > currently.  That means that over time the population w=
ill kind 
of
> > > dance around the behavior space until it hits a stepping=
 stone 
to
> > > something different.  It could take a long time, but at le=
ast 
it 
> > will
> > > never just sit still and "give up" the way fitness-=
based 
evolution
> > > tends to do when it converges prematurely.  Novelty =
search never
> > > "feels" like it has found an optimum because it is effec=
tively
> > > coevolutionary and always looking to break free.
> > > 
> > > =
There also may be something more active we can do to push it out
> > > beyo=
nd this inherent dynamic.  Maybe there is a method of 
detecting
> > > that=
 things are not diversifying well anymore and then pushing 
> > things
> > =
> out.  Yet we would need to be careful because simply e.g. 
upping the
> >=
 > mutation rate might make things worse by knocking our 
population off
> =
> > the current set of behaviors back to something more primitive.  
> > St=
ill,
> > > since this research direction is in its infancy, I'd guess 
ther=
e 
> > will
> > > end up many creative ideas for dealing with various bad 
=
situations,
> > > just as people have come up with all kinds of tricks to d=
eal 
with
> > > pathologies in fitness-based search.

the

s the relationship 
between

> > > > > search (NS) and exhausti=
ve search of behavioral space.  Do 
we

tively the same thing?

ut in the end I would not 
equate 
> > NS 
> > > > to

search.  While NS indeed does attempt to 
essentially 
> > > > visit
> > > =
> > every behavior in behavioral space, the way it does it is 
not 
> > the=
 
> > > > same
> > > > > as what is usually meant by exhaustive search.  We=
 usually 
> > think of 
> > > > an
> > > > > exhaustive search as a purpose=
ful enumeration, where if I 
just 
> > try
> > > > > every combination of s=
omething, one will be the answer.  A 
key 
> > > > feature
> > > > > of thi=
s type of search is that it does not require or 
utilize
> > > > > informat=
ion or feedback of any kind as a guide.  Rather, it 
> > simply
> > > > > m=
akes sure it does not visit the same point twice.  (It is 
> > similar 
> >=

> > > > > random search except that random search might indeed visi=
t 
the 
> > same
> > > > > point twice.)
> > > > > 
> > > > > One clear dif=
ference between such a search and NS is that 
we 
> > cannot
> > > > > purp=
osefully enumerate all possible behaviors because our 
> > search 
> > > > =
space
> > > > > is the genotype space, which maps indirectly to the 
behavi=
or 
> > space.

> > possible
> > > > > behaviors" and try each one in successio=
n.  We must seek 
them 
> > out.

ty search there is *information* 
guiding 
> > the
> > > > > order of point=
s we visit (the information is the novelty

ints also have an inherent order (perhaps quite 
useful) 
> > > > induced
>=

with
>=

in an
>=

most 
> >=

> > > > > trails that seem to be leading to something new.
>=
 > > > > 
> > > > > One significant consequence of this fact is that the ac=
tual 
> > search
> > > > > space (which is the genotype space) will almost =
certainly 
never 
> > need
> > > > > to be exhaustively searched.  So we ef=
fectively avoided 
wasting 
> > our
> > > > > time examining all kinds of g=
enetic combinations that would 
have
> > > > > produced redundant behaviors=
.  In its usual meaning, 
exhaustive 
> > > > search
> > > > > would be jus=
t such a search through genotype space.  So 
> > certainly it
> > > > > is =
not normal exhaustive search.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Yet if you still want to=
 talk about exhaustively searching 
> > behavior
> > > > > space, it is sti=
ll not a typical exhaustive search because 
of 
> > the 
> > > > fact
> > >=
 > > it proceeds in an order guided by information- not typical 
of
> > > >=
 > exhaustive search.  Another corollary is that it is 
impossible 
> > to
=
> > > > > perform a typical exhaustive search of behavior space 
because 
>=
 > we 
> > > > have
> > > > > no method to enumerate it:  It must be explor=
ed.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Yet you might still say, fine, semantically perhap=
s it is 
> > something
> > > > > different, but still, in spirit are you no=
t essentially 
doing
> > > > > something equally inefficient, i.e. looking =
for absolutely 
> > > > everything?  
> > > > > 
> > > > > And it is true t=
hat in effect we are searching for every 
> > behavior, 
> > > > or
> > > >=
 > at least every behavior that looks distinguishable from 
each 
> > other=

> > > > > with respect to the novelty metric and in an order from 
> > sim=
plicity 
> > > > to
> > > > > high complexity.  Yet therein lies the fundam=
ental insight: 
> > While 
> > > > such
> > > > > a search might sound bad,=
 it is a lot better to look at 
> > everything 
> > > > (in
> > > > > some =
meaningful order) and eventually run across what you 
want
> > > > > (perha=
ps after a very long time) than to look for one 
specific 
> > thing
> > > =
> > and *never* find it.
> > > > > 
> > > > > We are indeed suggesting that=
 this rather tortured choice 
> > (between
> > > > > looking for something =
without hope and looking for 
everything) 
> > is
> > > > > sometimes the r=
eal choice that we face with the most 
ambitious
> > > > > problems.  In ot=
her words, objective-based fitness is 
literally 
> > > > doomed
> > > > > =
when it comes to evolving many incredibly complex systems 
from
> > > > > s=
cratch.  It will simply never happen because at high 
levels of
> > > > > c=
omplexity, there is going to be massive deception at many

> >=
 > > and
> > > > > fitness becomes as bad as random search in such a proble=
m.  
In 
> > fact,
> > > > > as our results show, you don't even have to ma=
ke the 
problem 
> > all 
> > > > that
> > > > > hard to cause fitness to c=
rumble into something as bad as 
random
> > > > > search.  What do you thin=
k will happen if you are trying to 
> > evolve a
> > > > > neural network i=
nto the mind of a quantum physicist based 
on how
> > > > > brilliant it is=
 at quantum physics?  The answer: Nothing.
> > > > > 
> > > > > A more down=
-to-earth example is the car that I evolved on 
> > > > Picbreeder.
> > > >=
 >  It could never have evolved if evolving a car had been the
> > > > > *o=
bjective* because it was preceded by an alien face 
(evolved by
> > > > > s=
omeone else).  It just so happens that the alien face is a 
> > stepping
> =
> > > > stone to a car, but if we had judged the alien face on 
it "car-
> =
> > > ness,"
> > > > > it would have failed miserably and been deleted.  He=
nce if 
we 
> > were
> > > > > looking for a car we would never have found =
one.

> > > > > In nature, if we had bred flatworms (the earliest=
 
chordates) 
> > based 
> > > > on
> > > > > their humanity, they too woul=
d have never evolved into 
> > amphibians,
> > > > > then reptiles, then ma=
mmals, as they did.  The objective in 
> > long-run
> > > > > problems is t=
otally blind to the necessary stepping 
stones.  
> > Unless 
> > > > we
> =
> > > > know them a priori, we are lost.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Why do you su=
ppose we have never seen a flowering of 
diversity 
> > and
> > > > > compl=
exity such as seen in nature in evolutionary 
computation?  
> > In 
> > > =
> 30
> > > > > or 40 years of this field, which is inspired by nature, we 
=
have 
> > > > never
> > > > > seen something that comes even close to even =
nature's modest
> > > > > achievements.  The problem is that we have been b=
linded by 
> > > > objectives.
> > > > >    As soon as we set an objective,=
 the stepping stones to 
it 
> > often
> > > > > vanish into thin air.  The=
re is no escape from this very 
> > sobering
> > > > > fact.  It will have =
to be accepted, though it will be hard 
to 
> > > > accept.

> > =
> > > Novelty search cures this problem, although admittedly in a 
> > pain=
ful
> > > > > way, because it forces us to let go of our natural desire 
to=
 
> > > > *control*
> > > > > what is happening.  We feel compelled to dema=
nd to the 
search
> > > > > algorithm that it go in a certain direction.  I=
t is 
difficult to
> > > > > relinquish this feeling of control, yet if we =
recognize 
that in 
> > the
> > > > > end the setting of such goals is its =
own worst enemy, then 
we 
> > can
> > > > > begin to be liberated from thi=
s longstanding compulsion.

> > > > > (Note that I am not saying =
fitness is always useless; 
obviously 
> > that
> > > > > is not the case. =
 I am talking about very ambitious 
problems, 
> > beyond
> > > > > the kin=
d we have been able to solve yet- though even 
the "hard 
> > maze"
> > > >=
 > is bordering on such a problem.)

> > > > > off=
shoot in behavior space.  And yes, in some situations, 
it 
> > very 
> > >=

> > domains.

of the 
maze, 
> > first,
> > > > > since there is a time limit for each ro=
bot, it would make

> > > > > difference and would quickly be filled=

in the offshoot, it would be filled

ut at the same time, novelty search is not likely to go

> > in 
> > >=
 > only

l 
go

the

ll begin 
to 
> > flow

ppens to take the wrong paths,

> > > > > fill that areas firs=
t and eventually be pushed back into

> > > > > =
care about (only if each individual was given infinite time

course there is a chance it will fail to go

n reasonable time; after all, it has no objective!  In

s-

> > > > > search.  So the point is not that this is a guarante=
e 
(there 
> > will
> > > > > never be one).  Rather, it is a profoundly di=
fferent kind 
of

t fitness-based search 
can

utation.  That does not mean it solves

jective

hese

n exciting liberation.  If we let go of

pulsion to have some shred of guidance to hang onto
